title: Synthetic Recap
body:
NEW YORK — In the crucible of a grinding Eastern Conference battle, Patrick Ewing delivered a performance for the ages, single-handedly dismantling the Philadelphia 76ers with a Herculean effort that powered the New York Knicks to a 95-83 victory in 1998.

From the opening tip, this was a defensive war, a hallmark of the era. But Ewing stood as an unbreakable fortress in the paint. While Allan Houston’s 20 points provided crucial support, the night belonged solely to the Knicks’ center. Ewing was an unstoppable force, pouring in a game-high 43 points on a remarkably efficient 16-of-24 shooting from the field. He was a menace on both ends, hauling in 14 rebounds and anchoring a Knicks defense that held the 76ers to a paltry 36% shooting.

Philadelphia, led by Allen Iverson’s 21 points, simply had no answer. Every double-team was met with a decisive pass from Ewing, and every single-coverage resulted in a turnaround jumper or a powerful move to the rim. His dominance inside was so complete that it opened the floor for Houston and others, creating the offensive balance the Knicks needed to pull away.

The final score belies the sheer force of Ewing’s will. On a night where points were at a premium, his 43 were a monument to individual greatness within a team framework. It was a legendary outing from a legendary Knick, a reminder that in the heart of Madison Square Garden, a dominant big man could still take over a game and carry his team to victory. Ewing didn’t just win the game; he owned it.
